text: @Alyssa_Milano @realDonaldTrump 26 years ago .I was 7 and I still have not filed complaints. I must act quickly because in France, after 30 years, there is prescription. Because I was 9 & didn't understand what had happened. 
Because I tried to tell my mom & brother what his friend did, but they didn't understand. 
Because I then repressed the memories until I was older & my school played a video explaining assault & molestation.

@AshleyJudd I was being threatened at home; bullied at school. I started to cut class & run away. My grades slipped. I drank with friends. I was labled a 'bad kid.' No adult ever asked me what was wrong. It happened at a friend's house on a night I'd ran away. I had no one.#WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport because I felt responsible since we had discussed having sex prior & I flirted w/him & invited him over, so when I changed my mind since he didn‚Äôt bring a condom & he, only slipped it in once for a second despite my saying I wasn‚Äôt okay with it, l felt at fault

'I was drugged & raped in the Navy. The MP told me if I filed a report I would be charged with adultery because my rapist was married. I would lose my benefits & face a dishonorable discharge. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs chalk this up to a bad choice on your part‚Äù.'

Because we were together & everyone loved him. Because my friend bought us drinks at a bar & we're underage. I was told by family to not tell others. Because i told a friend & they told me 'it's opportunity to teach him'. Because it wasn't just me he assaulted.

I didn‚Äôt say anything because I was 16.  I felt worthless, ashamed, & alone. I thought it was my fault even though I was unconscious. I didn‚Äôt have the emotional strength to fight the battle... I was crushed. 20 years on I still have issues w/trust & self worth. #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport because I felt responsible since we had discussed having sex prior & I flirted w/him & invited him over, so when I changed my mind since he didn‚Äôt bring a condom & he, only slipped it in once for a second despite my saying I wasn‚Äôt okay with it, l felt at fault

Him weeks later, but I remained the liar. Hadn't seen him since that day 5 years ago, until I ran into him last night at Costco. I didn't know he worked there. Scared, I hid in an aisle & broke down. Waited a bit then I gathered myself and left. I'm traumatized #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport: bc I thought I deserved it. bc I fucked his friend afterword to take control. bc it'd happened in other forms before. bc I'd said no, bc I'd screamed, bc I'd fought, and it didn't matter. bc I thought my body was all I had to offer. bc no one believed me before.

#WhyIDidntReport

Details r vivid, yet sketchy. My stepftr did it, so in my 11-yr old mind, it was OK for the neighbor to. In my family u toughed it out. U went 2 church, prayed about it & let it go. I‚Äôm trying 2 change that, esp. in Black communities. Pray, but then run & tell!.  #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport -- I tried.  I was told to not take it seriously and 'just forget about it.'  That my abuser was 'didn't  realize what they were doing.'  They are six years my elder.  They knew 'no.'  It's one of my earliest memories and I wish I could bleach it from my brain.

#WhyIDidntReport
I was terrified that nobody would believe me. I thought that I‚Äôd be the one blamed & judged for what happened to me. I didn‚Äôt want my life to be ruined more than I already felt it was, & it felt safer to not report it, or even tell anyone at the time.

#WhyIDidntReport: I didn't know their names. I was too stunned to realize what happened. I was sober and terrified and they were drunk and aggressive. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc. Etc.

#WhyIDidntReport because I was afraid he would get kicked out of the firehouse. That he'd loose all his friends. I was afraid he'd loose his job. I was afraid he'd go to jail. I was afraid we wouldn't be able to be together. I was afraid he would have gotten rid of me.

I was 5 years old the first time. He ripped my shirt when I tried to get away. I got yelled at for that. I never said how it was ripped. I didn't think about it again until I was 28 and it came flooding back in the form of a flashback. I was terrified. #whyididntreport

I DID report; but only the first time. When the police told me it was my own fault for dressing 'provocatively' at 12 y/o, I lost faith in the system's ability to serve justice. So I didn't report the second time. Or the third. Victims deserve better. #WhyIDidntReport

I was, at one time, attracted to him. I, at one time, trusted him. I said yes to going to coffee with him. I got in the truck with him. It wasn‚Äôt violent. Maybe I didn‚Äôt say no ENOUGH. Maybe I gave him the wrong idea. He was a police officer.  #WhyIDidntReport #metoo

#WhyIDidntReport  I was 12 years old.  I didn't have the language.  The man was a neighbor.  I was afraid my father would kill him.  I was afraid that my father wouldn't kill him.  I thought my parents knew what happened and that they didn't think it was important.

#WhyIDidntReport

He's a family member.

And... well....

You can't go fucking shit up in the family, you know?

So I kept quiet for over 15 years.

But not ONE SINGLE DAY went by without me thinking about it.

Quite honestly, I'm still fucked in the head over it.

5. I would be told it was my fault because of the way I look
6. I would be told it was my fault because 'boys will be boys'
7. I would be told it was my fault because I put myself in that situation
8. I would be told it didn't mean anything. #WhyIDidntReport

I did too. It didn't matter either. I was ashamed. While I stood terrified at the teachers desk trying to report it, 'she' giggled...she actually giggled.
#WhyIdidntreport #MeToo

I've only just begun slowly getting back to who I was before the abuse. A happy, bright, optimistic, exuberant girl. Telling my story feels like putting all of that progress on the line. I don't want to be that scared, hollow girl again. #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport 
My abuser was my best friend‚Äôs, step brother. I told my ex bf, and was victim shamed for being in pajama shorts. Asking for it. I figured it‚Äôd be easier to disappear from my best friend and avoid further victim shaming from her family.

First time, I was 16, it was two strangers on a train in Soviet Russia. Got away, but half scared to death. I did tell the trip chaperone, but what could he do? 28 yrs later, thinking about it = smell of their Belomorkanal cigs and BO.  #WhyIDidntReport

My paternal grandfather did it to my brothers. Then to me when I was a baby. Then my brother did it to me. I was seven. All I knew was that it felt icky, but my brother said it was ok. He didn't know any better. How do you report that? #whyIdidntreport

#WhyIDidntReport
Because I was 9
... I didn't know what to say

... I thought grownups would say it was my fault

... I was ashamed

I told 2 friends. They didn't believe me then later blamed me saying I 'shouldn't have gotten drunk than'. I assumed the police would feel the same way. I didn't want to face my accuser in court. Plus I didn't even know his name.  #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport - I was 15, he was 21 & I saw him almost daily. The 1 friend I did tell thought I was 'lucky' - I felt guilty, embarrassed, and scared of judgement and/or repercussions.  I didn't start to open up until I was in my late 20s.

#WhyIDidntReport because it wasn‚Äôt rape. But it was unwanted sexual advances, but I still have to avoid him at a place I go every week. And no one knows why, except the person I called that picked me up from a street I didn‚Äôt know in salt lake.

#WhyIDidntReport The 1st time I was 4. I didn't remember it until I was 22. He was my mom's stepdad. All those yrs of wondering why I hated dresses & would have a panic attack over the thought of wearing one. I'm sure it wasn't the 1 time.

I only reported one because:
*No one believed the 2nd 
*I didn't believe the 3rd

Whether you've reported 1 or none, you are loved, you are whole, you are seen.

For those who need resources, @RAINN is a great place to start 
#WhyIDidntReport

#whyIdidntreport
Because he was a well known musician and we were in my apartment alone. I thought no one would believe I'd realized what kind of person he was and tried to throw him out but he had no intention of leaving.  It was terrible.

He was the family doctor and I was 21. I knew it would be his word against mine and I was only a college student. I wondered for years how many others were molested by the same doctor. #WhyWomenDontReport                    #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport He was my boyfriend at the time. Even if I said no it didn‚Äôt mean no to him. He would try things or make me try things cause ‚Äúif you love me you‚Äôll do it‚Äù and ‚Äúno one will ever love you like I do‚Äù. Coercion is not consent.

After my friend was assaulted and reported, I saw firsthand how horribly she was treated by the local justice system, our classmates, her attacker‚Äôs friends and the world. I didn‚Äôt think I could survive the same treatment. #WhyIDidntReport

I was 15 on an acting school trip in London. The adults were drinking and disorganized. I wanted more than anything to forget it. I never want to press charges because I don‚Äôt want to be put in the role of the accuser. #WhyIDidntReport

Because he was my best friend. Because I didn‚Äôt leave him right away. Because I was carrying his guilt & shame. 
Because I was scared of retaliation. 
Because it didn‚Äôt fit within the narrative of sexual assault. 
#WhyIDidntReport

Molested by my father during childhood...spoke to my mother when I was 9, told to ‚Äúnever mind‚Äù about it. Reminded her again in my 40‚Äôs & she couldn‚Äôt deny it anymore. She always knew & I knew not to speak up. #WhyIDidntReport

#WhyIDidntReport  he had me convinced that it was consensual since i felt forced to say yes because of threats. if i had said no (and i tried to say no) i would have gotten (and did get) hit. i was 15 and too scared to tell anybody

I made excuses. He was too drunk to process me saying no. It was at my house, so I must‚Äôve invited it. It would be too hard on my parents after already dealing w/my history of self-harm. I was already too broken.

#WhyIDidntReport  in the 80‚Äôs everything was wild. Drugs, alcohol, & sex. I had a huge love of making out, was in bed with a dude from a bar, & I told him that I wouldn‚Äôt have sex with him, so he hit me across the face.

@chickensaladgir Thank you for sharing. I finally told two people what happened. Afraid. Ashamed. Very young. Thought I‚Äôd be blamed. But I did nothing wrong. I didn‚Äôt deserve it. It was over 4-¬Ω decades ago. #WhyIDidntReport
